Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: The 2011 Atchafalaya River Flood and a possible altered system state for the Atchafalaya River Delta Estuary
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID research project will examine ecosystem and biogeochemical impacts of a 200-year flood of the Mississippi River along a transect from the Atchafalaya River, which is receiving massive inputs of water from the Morganza Spillway in addition to already high flood waters, to the Atchafalaya River Delta Estuary, to the northern Gulf of Mexico. The researchers will focus on how an extreme event in a river system having extensive interaction with wetlands and floodplain swamps alters carbon quality, nutrients, and sediment transport to the Gulf, as well as how these biogeochemical changes affect ecosystem respiration and the food web.

The broader impacts of the research include contributions to human resource development and to management issues. The project will interface with an existing Research Experience for Undergraduates program, affording students an opportunity to gain first-hand experience studying an extreme event in a floodplain river. Because extreme events such as this are expected to become more common in the future, this study will provide important information to managers, who currently must make decisions about river and flood management based on limited knowledge of the ecosystem effects of this type of event.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In spring 2011, record rainfall events in the Mississippi River basin resulted in a flood that broke many freshwater discharge and nutrient load records.  High flood waters resulted in the second opening of the Morganza Spillway (first since 1973) adding as much as 4,900 m3/s (peak flow on May 25th) to already near-record flows in the Atchafalaya River basin.  At its peak, over 23,000 m3/s of water passed through the Atchafalaya River into the Atchafalaya River Delta Estuary and the northern Gulf of Mexico. The overarching goal of this project was to capture both the short (rise, crest, and fall of the river hydrograph) and intermediate (one-year) time scale responses of the lower Atchafalaya River, the Atchafalaya River Delta Estuary, and ultimately the receiving waters of the northern Gulf of Mexico to this historic flooding event.  We examined how this extreme event altered carbon quality, nutrients, and sediment transport to the Gulf, as well as the impact of these biogeochemical changes on ecosystem respiration and the food web.  We compared measurements made before, during and after (2, 6, 9, 26, 39, and 50 weeks) peak discharge with 3 years of previous measurements. By leveraging this funding, we were able to acquire additional support that allowed us to continue our sampling to include 56, 66, and 102 weeks post-peak discharge.  Specifically, we quantified how the flood altered riverine particulate and dissolved carbon and nutrient fluxes, particulate organic carbon age-structure, and sediment transport and deposition rates and how these changes influenced water column and benthic respiration, nutrient uptake, and denitrification activity.  As a result of sizable number of samples collected during this project and the extension of field sampling as a result of leveraged support, we are still evaluating the results from this study. At this stage in our analysis, it is still a bit premature to assess the full extent of the impact of results from this study will ultimately have.  However, several interesting responses to the flood both in the river and the receiving waters of the Atchafalaya River Delta Estuary and the northern Gulf of Mexico have already been observed. Some of these findings were hypothesized (e.g. high riverine sediment loads and deposition rates in the estuary, suppression of benthic respiration rates following high levels of sedimentation, nutrient uptake and retention within the river and estuary system not increasing in proportion with flood river loads) while others were probably less expected (e.g. significant stimulation of respiration rates in the river that resulted in significantly lower dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water delivered to the estuary and benthic respiration remaining suppressed for approximately 2 years in some regions of the ARDE).

The broader impacts of this project included contributions to human resource development, outreach, and management. This project provided a research platform that supported the research and education activities of three early career principal investigators, one additional principal investigator, one early career collaborator, one underrepresented minority female PhD student, one MS student, two post-doctoral researchers, two research associates, two recent undergraduate research assistants, and three REU interns (two of which subsequently became research assistants on the project).  We have also engaged in numerous outreach activities targeting K-12, university, and public audiences often in conjunction with LUMCON’s diverse education programs.  The 2011 flood resulted in the largest discharge of water through the lower Atchafalaya River – ARDE system into the northern Gulf of Mexico hypoxic region on record.
